title: Process output does not wait for process to end
body:
I've just realized that in Rspec these two styles are different:

Version 1:

```
r = run 'myapp --list'
expect(r).to have_output /Usage:/
expect(r.exit_status).to eq 0
```

Version 2:

```
r = run 'myapp --list'
expect(r.output).to include 'Usage:'
expect(r.exit_status).to eq 0
```

Version 2 fails both expectations because only the custom matcher `have_output` waits for the command to finish before returning a result. Even in Version 1 the exit status check would have failed without the waiting of `have_output`

Is this the expected behaviour?

title: use conditional filters in RSpec tests to handle OS, Ruby Engine differences
body:
There are a number of places in the RSpec tests that are specific to a unix system and will fail on Windows because Windows doesn't implement that feature.  Instead of trying to come up with tests that will satisfy both Windows and "not Windows" operating systems, we should do what RSpec does with its testing:  use **conditional filters**.  
We could define some constant in `spec_helper.rb` that will tell us if the system is running on a Windows OS, like `WINDOWS = FFI::Platform.windows?`.  Then we can use `:unless => WINDOWS` to run specs that should only be run on non-Windows systems, and `if => WINDOWS` to run the test that should only be run on a Windows system.  

Here's an example of how it can be used:  

``` ruby
# in spec_helper.rb:
WINDOWS = FFI::Platform.windows?
```

``` ruby
# in spec\aruba\aruba_path_spec:

  describe '#blocks', :unless => WINDOWS do  
    let(:new_path) { expand_path('path/to/file') }

    before(:each) { FileUtils.mkdir_p File.dirname(new_path) }
    before(:each) { File.open(new_path, 'w') { |f| f.print 'a' } }

    it { expect(path.blocks).to be > 0 }
  end
```

The above example group will fail on Windows, because `.blocks` will always return `nil` since it's not implemented on Windows.  
There are quite a number of tests that will need this.  _File permissions_ is one area where there will need to be different tests for sure.  There may be some other file or directory related tests where this is needed.  

What do you think of using this approach?

title: Windows Environment Vars are converted to all upper case
body:
addresses #291 
`WindowsEnvironmentVars < Environment`  converts all ENV keys to upper case on initialization.  

`WindowsPlatform` now uses `WindowsEnvironmentVars` as its environment:

``` ruby
    class WindowsPlatform < UnixPlatform
      ...
      def environment_variables
        WindowsEnvironmentVars.new
      end
```

Rspec tests for `WindowsEnvironmentVars` included to be sure that accessing the environment variables by the keys will work and that `WindowsEnvironmentVars.keys` only has upper case chars.
-  I put the class into aruba/lib/platforms  but perhaps it should go somewhere else
-  "`WindowsEnvironmentVars.keys` only has upper case chars." really means that it only checks to be sure that none of the keys match `/[a-z]+/`  I think that might not catch lower case unicode chars that don't get 'upper-cased' by `[String].upcase`
  - Is this is worth including a gem that does unicode checking and 'upper-casing' so that we can be sure to check this? (like [unicode_utils](https://github.com/lang/unicode_utils))   Or should we wait until someone has an issue with it and then deal with it?

title: Introducing the Ports & Adapters to `aruba`'s codebase
body:
This is the PR for #298. It introduces three classes to aruba, which abstract the os specific code. @mattwynne Matt, is this what you've in mind? Pinging @weedySeaDragon as well.

I split this PR in several commits, each one can be reviewed by it's own.

title: Make "Platform" to abstract OS-specific things
body: We have a few place where we need to do things differently. Let's introduce [this pattern](http://alistair.cockburn.us/Hexagonal+architecture) to `aruba` as suggested by @mattwynne in https://gitter.im/cucumber/aruba and discussed with @weedySeaDragon.

title: Improve `which` for UNIX and Non-unix enviroments
body:
`which` is not a suitable name as it's to Unix-specific. Let's use something different, e.g. `expand_command` similar to `expand_path`.

To implement this, we could use code like this

``` ruby
class WindowsPlatform
  def expand_command(program, path = ENV['PATH'])
    Platform::WindowsCommandExpander.new(path).expand(program)
  end
end
```

``` ruby
class UnixPlatform
  def expand_command(program, path = ENV['PATH'])
    Platform::UnixCommandExpander.new(path).expand(program)
  end
end
```

I'm not sure where to move the created files best, maybe under
`lib/aruba/platform/windows_command_expander` and then create another file
`lib/aruba/platform/unix_command_expander.rb`?

Then create some classes:

``` ruby
class UnixCommandExpander
  private

  attr_reader :path

  public
  def initialize(path)
    @path = path
  end

  def expand(program)
  end
end
```

``` ruby
require 'aruba/platform/unix_command_expander'

class WindowsCommandExpander < UnixCommandExpander
  private

  attr_reader :path

  public

  def initialize(path)
    @path = path
  end

  def expand(program)
  end
end
```

title: Buffered output to stdout causes tests to pass locally but fail on Travis CI
body:
The application I am testing is a command line utility that spawns two child processes which both communicate to each other over a socket.  When trying to use the `Then the output should contain: ....` assertion, my tests pass locally however I get no output on my Travis CI builds.  Of the two child processes one of them is a javascript CLI and the other is a php CLI.  For my failing assertions, one of them is related to output not showing up from the javascript process and the other three are from the php process. On the php side I have modified my php.ini settings to not buffer stdout using:

``` php
ini_set('implicit_flush', 'on');
ini_set('output_buffering', 'off');
```

and also when printing to stdout:

``` php
fprintf(STDOUT, "Text to print");
flush()
```

So my output on the php side should not have any issues but it continues to fail.  The javascript process is an open source project that I have not written myself.  It prints the data to stdout by use of `console.log(data);`

The other interesting thing is I also run PHPUnit tests after my cucumber tests that check for output and those run just fine.  So I am unsure if this is an aruba/cucumber problem or something with my php or javascript cli program but I was hoping someone could point me in the right direction and would greatly appreciate any help.

Here is the travis [ci build](https://travis-ci.org/ddelnano/dredd-hooks-php) and the [github repo](https://github.com/ddelnano/dredd-hooks-php) of the code.

title: Windows ENV variables are case-insensitive (but not to Ruby)
body: Windows treats its environment variables without regard to the CASE. That is, in Windows, the environment variable 'PATH' == 'Path' == 'PaTh' == 'patH' etc. Using ENV to query the environment variables from Windows is also case-insensitive. So: ENV['PATH'] == ENV['Path'] However, once that information is brought into Ruby (e.g. by something like environment = ENV.to_hash, then case matters. In this case, the keys in environment _are_ case sensitive. So environment['PATH'] is _not_ equal to environment['Path'] This is causing failure anywhere that ENV['PATH'] is used. (Specs and features that depend on this all fail under Windows.) ENV['Path'] = __ is what is copied into @environment But the key used is still 'Path' (mixed case). But in the rest of the code, the key 'PATH' is used. Since nothing exists for that key, things don't happen like they should. I suggest that the use of ENV['PATH'] be isolated (turned in to a method call). Then any initial case conversion can be done privately (e.g. change things to upper case before any comparison is done with ENV['PATH']). I'm not sure where such a method should go. (I haven't explored it.)

title: Fix problem if working directory does not exist
body:
If someone does not run `setup_aruba` before `write_file` and all other `aruba`-methods, it fails with `Errno::ENOENT`.

This PR refactors the `expand_path`-method not to rely on the existence of the working directory.  Plus, a warning and some example were added about the correct use.

title: File permissions are platform specific; tests fail on Windows
body: For both 0.7.4 and 0.8.0 the tests for file permissions in spec/aruba/api_spec.rb are using Unix-platform specific tests. Thus these tests will always fail on Windows platforms. From Ruby Core 2.2.2 - File (http://ruby-doc.org/core-2.2.2/File.html) : ``` In the description of File methods, permission bits are a **platform-specific** set of bits that indicate permissions of a file. [... paragraph on Unix permission bits...] On non-Posix operating systems, there may be only the ability to make a file read-only or read-write. In this case, the remaining permission bits will be synthesized to resemble typical values. For instance, on Windows NT the default permission bits are 0644, which means read/write for owner, read-only for all others. The only change that can be made is to make the file read-only, which is reported as 0444. ```

title: v 0.8.0 'which' is unix specific (doesn't work on Windows)
body: 'which' is a unix-specific command; it doesn't exist on Windows ('where' is a close equivalent). Also, checking a PATH for the existence of a command does not work the same in Windows. There is code in spawn_process.rb and debug_process.rb that uses 'which' and checks the PATH. This won't work on Windows. I'm not clear on what the intent is. I can help with a PR if you can help me better understand the intent.

title: v 0.7.4 ChildProcess on Windows requires "cmd.exe /c"
body: Using version 0.7.4 on Windows, in run! Child.Process.build(....) fails with a ChildeProcess LaunchError. Here's a simple example running a cucumber scenario that uses aruba to call "rake spec" Here's the cucumber scenario: ``` Feature: Newly created rails gem is A-OK A rails gem that has just been created by the bundler should pass basic spec tests @announce @rail_gem Scenario: A newly created gem passes all spec tests Given the empty file named "test.tmp" When I run `rake spec` Then the output should contain "0 failures" ``` and here's the error that happens when running it: ``` > bundle exec rake cucumber Feature: Newly created rails gem is A-OK A rails gem that has just been created by the bundler should pass basic spec tests @announce @rail_gem Scenario: A newly created gem passes all spec tests # features\generator_new_gem.feature:7 Given the empty file named "test.tmp" # aruba-0.7.4/lib/aruba/cucumber.rb:47 $ cd C:/Users/ashley/RubymineProjects/ammeter $ rake spec When I run `rake spec` # aruba-0.7.4/lib/aruba/cucumber.rb:119 The system cannot find the file specified. (error #2 -(size 44) (Aruba::LaunchError) features\generator_new_gem.feature:9:in `When I run `rake spec`' Then the output should contain "0 failures" # aruba-0.7.4/lib/aruba/cucumber.rb:166 Failing Scenarios: cucumber features\generator_new_gem.feature:7 # Scenario: A newly created gem passes all spec tests 1 scenario (1 failed) 3 steps (1 failed, 1 skipped, 1 passed) 0m0.047s ``` Per https://github.com/jarib/childprocess/issues/59, on Windows, ChildProcess requires you to start any shell commands with "cmd.exe /c". The following code works for me: ``` def run! @process = ChildProcess.build(*Shellwords.split(@cmd)) # Windows needs to prepend commands with 'cmd.exe /c' @see from https://github.com/jarib/childprocess/issues/59 @process = ChildProcess.build(*(Shellwords.split(@cmd).unshift("cmd.exe", "/c"))) if ChildProcess.windows? ``` Would you like a PR for this?

title: Gemfile excludes windows for many gems (ex: rubocop)
body: Using the master (v. 0.8.0) The lines like ``` platform :ruby_20, :ruby_21, :ruby_22, :jruby, :rbx do ``` in the Gemfile are specifying **platforms,** not ruby versions or engines. These lines do not include any windows platforms. See http://bundler.io/man/gemfile.5.html ``` ruby C Ruby (MRI) or Rubinius, but NOT Windows mri Same as ruby, but not Rubinius (= C Ruby but not rubinius and not Windows) rbx Same as ruby, but only Rubinius (not MRI) (= rubinius but not MRI and not Windows) ``` (Note that cygwin development is reported as MRI.) In the Gemfile, this conditional excludes Windows ``` platform :ruby_19, :ruby_20, :ruby_21, :ruby_22, :jruby, :rbx do gem 'rubocop', '~> 0.32.0' end ``` So the rubocop gem will not be installed on any windows platform. The same issue applies to: byebug, prybug, pry-stack_explorer, bkat, kramdown, cucumber-pro, license-finder, relish . Are these lines supposed to be testing the ruby version or engine?

title: Aruba 0.7 can't be parsed on ruby 1.8.7 (and it generates a number of warnings)
body:
Our RSpec travis builds are getting this for 1.8.7:

```
/home/travis/.rvm/rubies/ruby-1.8.7-p374/lib/ruby/site_ruby/1.8/rubygems/core_ext/kernel_require.rb:54:in `gem_original_require': /home/travis/build/rspec/bundle/ruby/1.8/gems/aruba-0.7.2/lib/aruba/api.rb:293: syntax error, unexpected tIDENTIFIER, expecting tAMPER or '&' (SyntaxError)
    def copy(*source, destination)
                                 ^
/home/travis/build/rspec/bundle/ruby/1.8/gems/aruba-0.7.2/lib/aruba/api.rb:956: dynamic constant assignment
    DEFAULT_TIMEOUT_SECONDS = 3
                             ^
/home/travis/build/rspec/bundle/ruby/1.8/gems/aruba-0.7.2/lib/aruba/api.rb:966: dynamic constant assignment
    DEFAULT_IO_WAIT_SECONDS = 0.1
                             ^
/home/travis/build/rspec/bundle/ruby/1.8/gems/aruba-0.7.2/lib/aruba/api.rb:976: dynamic constant assignment
    DEFAULT_ROOT_DIRECTORY = Dir.getwd
                            ^
/home/travis/build/rspec/bundle/ruby/1.8/gems/aruba-0.7.2/lib/aruba/api.rb:984: dynamic constant assignment
    FIXTURES_PATH_PREFIX = ?%
                          ^
/home/travis/build/rspec/bundle/ruby/1.8/gems/aruba-0.7.2/lib/aruba/api.rb:986: dynamic constant assignment
    DEFAULT_FIXTURES_DIRECTORIES = %w(
                                  ^
/home/travis/build/rspec/bundle/ruby/1.8/gems/aruba-0.7.2/lib/aruba/api.rb:1202: syntax error, unexpected kEND, expecting $end
```

Does Aruba 0.7 no longer support Ruby 1.8.7?  Ideally support would have been dropped in a major version (e.g. 1.0).  If you didn't intend to drop 1.8.7 support please get a patch release out with a fix ASAP and look into why your CI build process didn't catch this regression.

title: Confusing post-install message
body:
> From aruba > 2.0 ruby 1.9.3-support is discontinued

Should this say `aruba >= 1.0`?  It seems odd to drop support for a ruby version in 2.1, given that it's not SemVer compliant at all and the current version is 0.7.

BTW, I don't see a github tag for the 0.7.x release which makes it hard to navigate to them.  And `History.md` hasn't been updated for those releases.

title: Do not trigger Announcer API deprecation warning
body:
`Processes::SpawnProcess#stop` calls `Announcer::PutsAnnouncer#stderr` and `#stdout`, triggering [these](https://github.com/cucumber/aruba/blob/abd78e67237e5951bb3256d9235bfc6597db22c9/lib/aruba/announcer.rb#L137) [two](https://github.com/cucumber/aruba/blob/abd78e67237e5951bb3256d9235bfc6597db22c9/lib/aruba/announcer.rb#L142) deprecation warnings in third party projects that use Aruba.

This fixes the problem. :)

title: Remove Aruba::Reporting
body: AFAIK this was an experiment to generate docs for Cucumber from Aruba. I don't know anyone who uses it, and it adds maintenance overhead (e.g. #275). Unless anyone puts up a good argument, I say we remove it in the next release.

title: Updating Vendored JQuery
body: The currently vendored version of JQuery has an open cross-site scripting vunerability (CVE-2011-4969). While this is probably not even a thing to most people, in an enterprise risk-averse environment a project using aruba can potentially be blocked from deploying due to the vendored version of JQuery even being present. Updating to the latest JQuery.

title: Decouple announcer from events by introducing an event queue
Refactor names of methods
body: - get rid of short names like _dir, _env, ...

title: Add configuration to aruba
body:
- which can modified globally
- from cucumber
- from rspec

title: Add debug mode for command execution
body: Use `@debug`-tag for this to make it open a `pry` or `irb`-shell

title: Move documentation of aruba to some documentation service
body:
- use relish
- use middleman-extension
- build cucumber-reporter for this
- use cucumber-html reporter for this

title: Refactor announcer to support user defined announce channels
Use development branch for new features
body: Maybe we should introduce a development branch, otherwise the README on master may contain invalid information.

title: Time to release a new gem version?
body: The last gem release was in January but there's quite a lot of work on master. For example right now the README gives instructions to `require 'aruba/rspec'` in `spec_helper` but this doesn't actually work with the current 0.6.2.

title: Logo for aruba
body: Maybe we should create a cool logo for aruba?! @jarl-dk @mattwynne What do you think?

title: refactor out use_clean_gemset into RVM class
body:
Also fixes issues:
- now handles newer versions of RVM giving different `rvm gemset create` output
- GEM_PATH was incorrectly replaced (instead preserving @global gemset in path)

title: Move from features to documentation
body:
This PR moves from cucumber features as tests to cucumber features as documentation. It's WIP.

This needs #258 and #219 merged first for easier review.

title: Migrate to an observer pattern to inform code about changes going on
body:
This PR will bring event queues where code can register itself to get informed about changes.

Events
- change of current working directory
- change of environment variables
- new command started
- command stopped
- ...

This is based on PR #257 and #258. It's not finished yet.

title: Add configuration
body:
This will add a main configuration to aruba. See #246 This one now includes #257 and #219 because I needed some changes I made there.

To discuss:
- [ ] Use of [`contracts`-gem](https://github.com/egonSchiele/contracts.ruby) for configuration
- First Refactored feature test -> More Documentation then test - see features/commands/exit_statuses.feature.
- Relish Support
- Implementation of config
  - There's a global configuration which is dupped to runtime configuration
  - The configuration can be changed in rspec via metadata - does it make sense to port it to cucumber?

title: Cleanup "Process Management" #1
body: This one cleans up `Process Management`. Will create a new PR for the next iteration of cleanup.

title: Aruba Reporting is not compatible with cucumber 2
body:
@mattwynne @jarl-dk 

I took a look at `aruba/reporting.rb` because of #161. After I upgraded to cucumber 2.0.0, reporting does not work anymore. There seems to be some progress on changing the Formatter API of cucumber.

Does it make sense to refactor the Reporting Module of aruba into a proper cucumber formatter? Seems to be doable and reasonable. What do you think?

References: cucumber/cucumber#839, cucumber/cucumber#851

title: Add FileTests as matchers to aruba
body: We could/should add http://ruby-doc.org/core-2.2.0/FileTest.html as matchers/methods to aruba to make tests more readable.

title: Add documentation for simplecov
body: Add documentation for simplecov

title: Really use expand path everywhere
body: #241 There are some recursive invocations. We need to have a look at it.

title: Path Content
body:
This reads content from
- directory
- file

And returns an array of content. Next step would be to use it "everywhere" in the code. `rubcop` complains if I use `ArgumentError` although that should be ok. For now I disabled the check.

title: Matcher improvements
body:
This is an alternative to #248.  It uses RSpec 3's support for composable matchers via `values_match?` and `description_of` for the description/failure messages.  The failure messages are derived from the description so we can just set that.  By using `values_match?` there's no need to treat the regexp, string or any other case as special.

Docs:

http://rspec.info/documentation/3.2/rspec-expectations/RSpec/Matchers/Composable.html#values_match%3F-instance_method

http://rspec.info/documentation/3.2/rspec-expectations/RSpec/Matchers/Composable.html#description_of-instance_method

Bear in mind that this will only work on RSpec 3+.  What versions of RSpec is aruba designed to support?  It may need to be rejiggered to support older versions of RSpec.

title: Use polymorphism for file content matcher
Diffable content
body:
@mattwynne 

Fix for diffable + A Fix for the failure message of the new file size matcher...

title: Extend/refactor Aruba.configure
body:
We should extend/refactor the existing `Aruba.configure`-mechanism to make it a place for default values of `aruba.`

https://github.com/cucumber/aruba/blob/master/lib/aruba/config.rb

@mattwynne 
Done.

title: Moving code to separate classes
body:
This is the first PR for #231. I kept the commits as isolated as possible, to make it easier to review the changes.

This PR is not yet finished. I think it needs to be discussed first. All "old" tests are passing with this code. It also duplicates the `capture`-method I used in some other PR. I only added it to make the tests pass. The documentation is not complete. Tests needs to be written.

Besides that I'm quite happy with the code:
- It support's the old API and adds a lot of deprecation warnings
- Now all announcer code is bundled and has a nice API which be extended easily by us and by users - see a very first version of an example in `lib/aruba/announcer.rb`
- The `announce_or_puts`-method is gone and replaced by `mode=`
- I introduced a `default_announcer` which writes to `/dev/null` and an announcer which writes to what ever announcer was chosen by `mode=` - e.g. `Kernel.puts`, `puts`
- At first I thought it might be a good idea to store the activated announcers in a `Hash`, but decided against it because we would end up with different activated `Announcers` if the mode is changed between two activations
- All process monitoring code is bundled in `ProcessMonitor` - BTW I'm open to rename if one of you guys has a better idea.

@jarl-dk @mattwynne 

Suggestions?

title: Add rspec integrator
body:
Make it easier for others to integrate `aruba` with rspec.

BTW and as a reminder for me in the future:
This https://github.com/jnicklas/capybara/blob/master/lib/capybara/rspec.rb is a good example.

We may need to discuss the `type`. I'm open for suggestions. What about `type: :aruba` or `type: :cli`?

title: Remove _file/_directory in method names
body:
When we have `file?` and `directory?` in place, I see no need to have `remove_file`, `remove_directory`   and `touch_file` anymore.

Be stating `_file` and `_directory` in the name we mix a test and an action. I think users should use the `file?` and `directory?`-methods for tests and `remove` and `touch` for actions.

I changed the implementation of the given methods to work both on files and directories. All relevant changes are from the 2nd of May.

This PR is based on #237.

title: Add Dennis Günnewig as a core contributor
body:
Hi @dg-ratiodata,

I've been really impressed with the amount of care and attention you've been giving to Aruba lately. We'd like to invite you to join the core team.

I would email you but it's private on GitHub. Please join the mailing list at https://groups.google.com/forum/#!forum/cukes-devs and we'll welcome you there!

We could try to arrange a Google Hangout for you, Jarl and I to discuss our ideas for Aruba. What do you think?

title: use expand path everywhere
body:
Follow up to #224.

@jarl-dk 

You changed the public API of `#absolute_path`. I think we should deprecate that API properly first. To make the switch easier for us I added the old implementation of `absolute_path` and left the new one to `expand_path`. What do you think?

To make it possible to use `expand_path` everywhere I removed the `prep_for_fs`-call, because otherwise we would have doubled the `tmp/aruba`-path in the expanded path.

Do you see any reason to keep the method as part of `aruba`. I mark it as deprecated.

I added single commits for the changes to make review easier. I will squash them after the review.

I also added a spec for the `absolute_path` as long as it is part of `aruba`. The deprecation warning is silenced.

title: Improve development environment
body:
1. Remove ruby 1.9.3 from supported rubies
   
   Ruby 1.9.3 is End of Life. I see no reason to officially support a ruby
   version which does not get any bugfixes from core developers.
2. Add support for JRuby 2 and 2.1 mode
3. Debugging
   
   `pry` seems to be the debugger-tool in the ruby-world. Together with byebug
   (ruby 2 only) even code walking is possible. The stack_explorer plugin gives
   you a nice access to the stack trace. The doc-plugin makes ruby doc available from within a pry session
4. License Finder
   
   `aruba` seems be used widely. So extra care should be taken with licensing
   issues. The [license_finder](https://github.com/pivotal/LicenseFinder) helps
   you with that. It tracks license of all uses libraries. I whitelisted the MIT
   and the BSD-licenses, I think there's no problem here. I excluded the gems
   which are part of the `development`-group. They are not needed for the
   core-functionality.

@jarl-dk @mattwynne  Feedback?

title: Make matcher have_permisions public and add documentation
body:
I think the `have_permissions`-matchers is usable for other people as well. I think we should remove the `@private`-flag.

``` ruby
describe 'my feature' do
  it { expect('file.txt').to have_permissions(0700) }
end
```

I also added a configuration file for `yardoc` and the directory which is generated by `yardoc` during documentation generation is ignored now.

@mattwynne @jarl-dk Suggestions?

title: Added matcher for file content
body:
I added a matcher to match string to file content. This might be useful for aruba internals as well, but is itended to be part of the public API.

This PR is based on a refactoring done in #237, that's why there are some more commits added here. I will rebase this PR.

title: Add matcher to check if file exists
body:
This adds a helper to check if a file exists in filesystem. This also resolves the full path. ~~This PR needs to be rebased if #224 is merged (absolute_path -> expand_path).~~

I added a separate spec file. This spec file uses the aruba api as well. To make the "aruba api object" `@aruba` re-usable I added a shared context for that.

title: When using Aruba::InProcess and RSpec undefined method `output`
body:
aruba 0.6.2
ruby 2.1.1p76

Exactly when using `output_from` method:

```
     Failure/Error: @last_output = output_from(command)
     NoMethodError:
       undefined method `output' for #<Aruba::InProcess:0x0000010569c700>
```

This monkey patch as a workaround makes my spec both blazingly fast and green:

``` ruby
class Aruba::InProcess
  def output
    stdout + stderr
  end
end
```

Not sure if it is correct in all edge cases but works for me.

Do you want me to create a PR with this new method for `Aruba::InProcess` ? I of course will add specs for this one.

If so, then do you have any suggestions to this implementation? Any edge cases I'm not aware of?
## 

KR, Oleksii.

title: Fix typo
body: Double `in` in README.md.

title: Make sure a file/directory does not exist + Cleanup named file/directory steps
body:
I often use an `init`-command to create some files. In my steps I try to make it obvious that the file should not exist. This PR adds new cucumber steps which makes the intent very clear and does not fail if I file/directory does not exist. This PR also includes a small refactoring - hope this is ok.

New steps
- Make sure file does not exist
- Make sure directory does not exist

Cleanup step
- Make directory step look the same like file step

I'm very well aware of the `I remove file/directory "xz.txt"`-step. But I think the intention is very different.

title: Use 1.x for cucumber to work around bug
body: Using `cucumber` "2.x" make tests fail for aruba. It looks like `cucumber` 2.x + `gherkin` 2.x doesn't work for the test suite of aruba. It looks like we should wait for `gherkin` 3 (see @aslakhellesoy [comment](https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber/issues/827#issuecomment-90483021) on this. This PR pins `aruba` to `cucumber` 1.x. The commit should be reverted when `gherkin` 3 is out.

title: Feature/root directory
body: PR based on comment from @jarl-dk on this PR #224.

title: Refactor API
body:
Hi @jarl-dk  @mattwynne ,

I would like to discuss the following things with you:
1. Move "Helper"-methods to `aruba/helpers.rb` - e.g. `absolute_path`
2. Move internal helpers to `aruba/utils.rb` and make them `module`-functions of `Aruba::Utils`
   
   '1.' and '2.' will make clear, what is part of the `aruba`-API
3. Migrate `check_*`-methods to `rspec`-matchers
4. Migrate `assert*`-methods to `rspec`-matchers
   
   '3.' and '4.' will make tests more readable + providing better error methods
   to users. And will make use of all the good things which come with
   `expect(x)`. And as we are already using `rspec` for the api-tests,
   testing of the new `matchers` will be dead simple.
   
   Alternative: Create more custom matchers to improve code.
   
   _Example_:
   
   **old**
   
   ``` ruby
   def check_file_size(paths_and_sizes)
    prep_for_fs_check do
      paths_and_sizes.each do |path, size|
        path = File.expand_path(path)
        expect(File.size(path)).to eq size
      end
    end
   end
   ```
   
   **new**
   
   ``` ruby
   def check_file_size(paths_and_sizes)
    prep_for_fs_check do
      paths_and_sizes.each do |path, size|
        path = File.expand_path(path)
        expect(path).to have_file_size size
      end
    end
   end
   ```
   
   Writing `rspec` tests using the `assert_*` looks very weird. I would prefer
   to have custom `rspec`-matchers for this.
   
   **old**
   
   ``` ruby
   def assert_partial_output(expected, actual)
    actual.force_encoding(expected.encoding) if RUBY_VERSION >= "1.9"
    expect(unescape(actual)).to include(unescape(expected))
   end
   ```
   
   **new**
   
   ``` ruby
   def assert_partial_output(expected, actual)
   $stderr.puts 'Deprecated'
    expect(actual).to include_content expected
   end
   
   # matcher
   RSpec::Matchers.define :include_content do |expected|
    match do |actual|
      actual.force_encoding(expected.encoding) if RUBY_VERSION >= "1.9"
   
      # Support real files as well
      actual = File.read(absolute_path(actual.to_s)).chomp if actual.is_a? Pathname
      Aruba::Utils.unescape(actual).include? Aruba::Utils.unescape(expected)
    end
   
    failure_message do |actual|
      format("expected that file \"%s\" has content \"%s\".", actual, expected)
    end
   
    failure_message_when_negated do |actual|
      format("expected that file \"%s\" does not have content \"%s\".", actual, expected)
    end
   end
   
   # test for string
   RSpec.describe 'includes content' do
     subject { 'string' }
   
     context 'when includes content' do
       it { is_expected.to include_content 'content a' }
     end
   
     context 'when not includes content' do
       it { is_expected.not_to include_content 'content c' }
     end
   end
   
   # test for file
   # this could made real by wrapping all the magic within a matcher
   RSpec.describe 'includes content' do
     subject { Pathname.new('file') }
   
     context 'when includes content' do
       before(:each) { write_file(subject, 'content a') }
       it { is_expected.to include_content 'content a' }
     end
   
     context 'when not includes content' do
       it { is_expected.not_to include_content 'content c' }
     end
   end
   
   ```
5. Add convenience-layer for `minitest`-users via `assert_*`-methods
6. Introduce `minitest` and `rspec`-require-files, e.g. `aruba/minitest` and `aruba/rspec`
   - `aruba/rspec`:
     
     ``` ruby
     require 'aruba/helpers'
     require 'aruba/utils'
     require 'aruba/matchers'
     ```
   - `aruba/minitest`:
     
     ``` ruby
     require 'aruba/helpers'
     require 'aruba/utils'
     require 'aruba/assertions'
     ```

title: Support for setting mtime when using #touch_file
body:
@jarl-dk 

When creating a fixture using `touch_file` it can be quite handy to set the timestamp to a fixed time. This PR makes this possible by passing through options to `FileUtils`.

This

``` ruby
touch_file 'file.txt', mtime: Time.parse('2014-01-01 10:00:00')
```

works like that

``` bash
#/bin/bash
touch -d '2014-01-01 10:00:00' file.txt
```

This also speeds up tests, because you do not need to do something nasty like this:

``` ruby
touch_file 'file.1.txt'
sleep 1
touch_file 'file2.txt'
```

@jarl-dk Would you mind to create a repository for creating a aruba-guides website?

I would suggest to use `jekyll` for this, though I must admit I know `middleman` better, but `jekyll` seems to be the default for github-pages.

title: Please consider restoring `#regexp` (removed in 0.6.2) and/or clarify what your public APIs are
body:
(Moving this issue from my comment on 5b2c7b445bc80083e577b793e4411887ef295660 since I realized it's really an issue and should be discussed here.)

In 5b2c7b445bc80083e577b793e4411887ef295660, `Aruba::API#regexp` was removed, which we relied upon in RSpec in some custom cucumber step definitions.  The 0.6.2 aruba release from a couple days ago broke our build:

https://travis-ci.org/rspec/rspec-core/jobs/47020617#L303

We (perhaps wrongly) assumed `regexp` was a public API since it wasn't labeled `@private`.  Would you consider adding it back and making it a public API? Otherwise we can work around it (which is fine).

Also, can you clarify what your API/versioning policy is?  Do you aim to follow the SemVer.org spec?  If so, what APIs do you consider public (and therefore subject to the SemVer.org spec)?  I'd like to make sure we're limiting what we use to just your public APIs so we don't run into this kind of thing again.

title: Rename *_dir to *_directory
body: Every method which works on a file is named `*_file`. Every method which works on a directory is named `*_dir`. While file is fully written, directory is abbreviated. This PR changes this. Now all methods are fully written.

title: Use new travis build infrastructure
body:
The guys @ TravisCI set up a new build infrastructure which supports "faster" build by using `docker`

See http://blog.travis-ci.com/2014-12-17-faster-builds-with-container-based-infrastructure/ for more information.

title: Add fixtures to aruba
body:
This PR adds the basics to support fixtures in `aruba`. Also see  #219.

Things to discuss:
- [ ] Use of `OpenStruct`
  
  I used `OpenStruct` here to make both paths of a fixture available: The relative one which is used to find a fixture and the absolute one, which can be used by a `consumer` of the api like `copy_file`. I can replace this by a `Hash` if this is preferred. Though `OpenStruct` is part of `ruby core distribution`.
- [ ] Use of `Pathname`
  
  I like the `relative_path_from`-functionality of `Pathname`. It makes the intention of the author clear and is quite easy to use to build relative paths.
- [ ] Use of `%/` as fixture path prefix
  
  It does not have a special meaning in ruby so far - besides percent classes which are not followed by `/`.
- [ ] Order of directories to be searched
  
  I use "my" preferred order here, but I'm open to change it.
- [ ] Commit Style
  
  I will refactor the "commits" after all things above are discussed to make sure that there's one commit for the tests and one commit for the implementation.
- [ ] Rubocop
  
  I think we will need to "guard" this [line](https://github.com/cucumber/aruba/pull/224/files#diff-65af44ccc0b346dd91178a015aee5560R39) and that [line](https://github.com/cucumber/aruba/pull/224/files#diff-65af44ccc0b346dd91178a015aee5560R786) here because of `===` (3x `=`). But `===` returns `true'/`false`for both`String`AND`Regexp`and thus is more flexible than`==`

title: with_env behaviour with multiple environment variables
body:
I see that recently @dg-ratiodata added a helpful method `with_env` to Aruba::API (#188) that allows you to run a block with environment variables set which are then restored back to original values.

However, the current implementation seems to run the block once for each env var you pass into the hash. 

```
    def with_env(env = {}, &block)
      env.each do |k,v|
        set_env k, v
        block.call
        restore_env
      end
    end
```

Is this the intended behaviour? 

Context: I want to set a series of env vars before running my process all together,

I can achieve this by calling the underlying methods directly, but I wondered whether you would be happy for me to change this method to set all the vars just once and then call the block. Something like:

```
    def with_env(env = {}, &block)
      env.each do |k,v|
        set_env k, v
      end

      block.call
      restore_env
    end
```

Appreciate that this breaks existing behaviour and so might be a breaking change for some people - so I would be happy to rename this method or use an alternative approach.

title: Aruba::Api.assert_partial_output_interactive() function name is misleading
body: assert_partial_output_interactive() does not use expect(), and therefore does not cause a failure when the text does not match.  Its use by `When I wait for (?:output|stdout) to contain...` needs for it to not fail, so its behavior is ok, but the name of the method is misleading. "Assert" conveys a sense that it will create a failure to occur if the expected condition is not met. Please change the name of the existing method, or adjust the design of the use of it by `When I wait for output to contain` to have it use expect() by default, but when given an optional argument, it suppresses the assertion.

title: Add force flag to remove_dir and remove_file
body:
It was not possible to force `#remove_file` to "delete" an not existing file. It just raised an error. I added a `force`-option, so that no error is raised if a file/directory does not exists.

To make `#remove_dir` backward-compatible I set `force` to `true`, because `Dir.rmdir` does not care if a directory exists or not.

title: Add copy method to aruba
body:
In one of my projects I need to copy files around during testing. I added a method to do this.

@jarl-dk Would you mind to review this?

title: Accept single and multiple files per method invocation
body:
There were methods which accept only a single file per method invocation and there were methods which accept multiple files (as arguments). I added functionality which makes it possible to use multiple files per method invocation. One does not need to put those file names in an array. I use the splat operator to make this possible. Though it is still possible to use an array of file names, because I "flatten" the file names array. The only "drawback" is, that it is not possible to set default values anymore if the splat operator is in use. I work around this by checking via `#nil?`.

``` ruby
touch_file 'file1', 'file2'
```

title: Use simplecov for coverage reports for specs and cucumber
body:
simplecov is a wrapper on the built-in coverage library for Ruby 1.9+.  When running `rake spec` or `rake cucumber`, a coverage report will be output in coverage/index.html.  If you run both tasks or all tasks with `rake spec` within a close enough time window (I think 10 minutes) the results will all be merged so you can get coverage across both the specs and features.  If this PR is accepts, then I'll add another to use coveralls.io to publish the coverage reports to coveralls.io, but someone with admin access will have to setup the hooks on coveralls.io for that.  Additionally, the reports from simplecov are a confirmation that not all steps are being exercised, include the ones dealing with rvm.  I have a fix for that too that I can post in a later PR.

![screen shot 2014-09-25 at 2 04 16 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2230482/4410585/09ea8eb6-44e7-11e4-9572-f7f83ba28451.png)
# Verifications Steps
## specs
- [ ] `rake spec`
- [ ] VERIFY no failures
- [ ] `open coverage/index.html`
- [ ] VERIFY coverage report includes specs
- [ ] `rm -rf coverage`
## cucumber
- [ ] `rake cucumber`
- [ ] VERIFY no failures
- [ ] `open coverage/index.html`
- [ ] VIERFY coverage report includes features and steps
- [ ] `rm -rf coverage`
## all
- [ ] `rake`
- [ ] VERIFY no failures
- [ ] `open coverage/index.html`
- [ ] VERIFY coverage includes specs, features, and steps

title: Use stub_const in favor of old, custom patch
body: With the introduction of `stub_const` in rspec-mocks 2.11, there was no need for `with_constants` since rspec can handle the constant stubbing itself now.  New code used `stub_const` inside the `with_constants` block, but no one went back yet to refactor the old code to use `stub_const`.

The configuration disables most `cops` for now so that the tests does not fail. Enabling the cops will be done in another PR, which also will fix those offenses. I split it up because there will be a lot offense/changes at first. This will also fix some style issues mentioned here #184.

title: Fix typos in readme
body:

title: Fix reporting when using 'Given a file named "filename"'
body:
With a _.feature_ file like this:

``` gherkin
  Scenario: use a file
    Given a file named "input" with:
    """
    test
    """
    When I run `cat test`
    Then the output should contain "test"
```

If I run `bundle exec cucumber`, the test will pass. If I enable reporting by setting the environment variable like this `export ARUBA_REPORT_DIR='/tmp/doc'; bundle exec cucumber`, the test will fail with a message like this:

```
      wrong number of arguments (1 for 0) (ArgumentError)
      /home/cvoltz/.rvm/gems/ruby-1.9.3-p448/gems/aruba-0.5.4/lib/aruba/spawn_process.rb:49:in `stderr'
      /home/cvoltz/.rvm/gems/ruby-1.9.3-p448/gems/aruba-0.5.4/lib/aruba/reporting.rb:27:in `block in pygmentize'
      /home/cvoltz/.rvm/gems/ruby-1.9.3-p448/gems/aruba-0.5.4/lib/aruba/spawn_process.rb:34:in `run!'
      /home/cvoltz/.rvm/gems/ruby-1.9.3-p448/gems/aruba-0.5.4/lib/aruba/reporting.rb:23:in `pygmentize'
      (erb):8:in `block in files'
      (erb):3:in `each'
      (erb):3:in `files'
      /mnt/fio/cvoltz/.rvm/rubies/ruby-1.9.3-p448/lib/ruby/1.9.1/erb.rb:838:in `eval'
      /mnt/fio/cvoltz/.rvm/rubies/ruby-1.9.3-p448/lib/ruby/1.9.1/erb.rb:838:in `result'
      /home/cvoltz/.rvm/gems/ruby-1.9.3-p448/gems/aruba-0.5.4/lib/aruba/reporting.rb:68:in `files'
      (erb):23:in `report'
      /mnt/fio/cvoltz/.rvm/rubies/ruby-1.9.3-p448/lib/ruby/1.9.1/erb.rb:838:in `eval'
      /mnt/fio/cvoltz/.rvm/rubies/ruby-1.9.3-p448/lib/ruby/1.9.1/erb.rb:838:in `result'
      /home/cvoltz/.rvm/gems/ruby-1.9.3-p448/gems/aruba-0.5.4/lib/aruba/reporting.rb:62:in `report'
      /home/cvoltz/.rvm/gems/ruby-1.9.3-p448/gems/aruba-0.5.4/lib/aruba/reporting.rb:105:in `block (2 levels) in <top (required)>'
      /home/cvoltz/.rvm/gems/ruby-1.9.3-p448/gems/aruba-0.5.4/lib/aruba/reporting.rb:104:in `open'
      /home/cvoltz/.rvm/gems/ruby-1.9.3-p448/gems/aruba-0.5.4/lib/aruba/reporting.rb:104:in `After'
```

The problem appears to be that in _reporting.rb_, the calls to _stdout_ and _stderr_ are supplying a parameter which is no longer implemented in _spawn_process.rb_. This patch removes the unused parameters, which lets the test pass with reporting enabled.

title: Fix rspec invokation in Rakefile due to changes in rspec 3.0.0 + fixes for deprecation warnings

In `rspec` 3.0.0 the support for the `nested`-format was removed. If I understand that correctly one should use `documentation` instead. 

Please see https://github.com/rspec/rspec-core/blob/26698e46d312802483cee456610508f92a3dde56/Changelog.md#300beta2--2014-02-17

```
Remove support for specifying the documentation formatter using 's',
'n', 'spec' or 'nested'. (Jon Rowe)
```

Along with this fix I also fixed some deprecation warnings:
- be_true -> be_truthy
- be_false -> be_falsey
- stub_const

title: Expand paths starting with "~"
body:
Hi there,

@jarl-dk would you mind to review this PR? :-)

I need to place config files in the home directory of the current user. I solved the problem by defining a step which modifies the `ENV['HOME']`-variable before each test and using the `~` to reference the home-directory. The only thing missing is the support in `aruba`. The `File.expand_path`-method is able to expand the `~` to the home-directory by using the `ENV['HOME']`-variable. 

I added the `File.expand_path`-method to all `aruba`-method to add support for `~`-expanding in all `aruba`-methods. There's also a step now, which mocks the `ENV['HOME']`-variable. 

To make testing a little bit easier I also added two helper `with_env` and `random_string`. The `with_env`-helper uses existing `aruba`-methods to change the process environment during testing for a block of code. The latter is used to generate a random string I used in some tests. I wanted to make sure to not delete files accidently outside `tmp/aruba` while using `~/file_name`.

Cheers,
dg

Standard begin/rescue/end block:

``` ruby
begin

rescue LoadError

end
```

Which works fine if not in a test. https://travis-ci.org/github/hub/jobs/13004803

The tests do not get caught in the infinite loop when the require is inside a method, such as

``` ruby

  load 'io/console'
rescue LoadError
  nil
end
```

Any idea what might be causing this?

title: Unexpected FakeKernel.exit behaviour
body:
Hello guys,

I'm using an in process setup because I want to use simplecov for coverage.

My code looks something like:

``` ruby
def execute!
  do_something_that_could_call_kernel_exit_1

  @kernel.exit(0)
end
```

Running directly on the shell triggering a failure returns exit status 1.
But my feature triggering the same failure always returns 0.

``` ruby
class FakeKernel
  attr_reader :exitstatus

  def initialize
    @exitstatus = 0
  end

  def exit(exitstatus)
    @exitstatus = exitstatus
    # should interrupt the execution somehow here
  end
end
```

`FakeKernel.exit` should stop the execution in my opinion.
By raising an exception maybe and silently catching it before the expectations.

What do you think about that??

I know this trivial example could be fixed by removing `@kernel.exit(0)` at the end,
but I think it would be good if `FakeKernel.exit` behaved like `Kernel.exit`.

Greetings,
Ed

title: Document "I close the stdin stream" for interactive processes that run indefinitely
body:
I ran into a [problem](https://github.com/zaaanderson/glittery/issues/1) a few months ago in which Aruba would time out when testing output from an interactive process that was still running when the "the stdout should contain" step ran. This is intended behavior in Aruba, of course, since it's supposed to wait for an interactive process to finish in order to prevent race conditions, but it wasn't clear to me that the "the stdout should contain" step would by default be affected by this feature.

An "I close the stdin stream" step has been added to Aruba that addresses this problem, but it's undocumented. I've added some brief documentation to the readme that describes how to use it to keep Aruba from timing out in a situation like this.

title: Close files on SpawnProcess#stop
body:
Alternate implementation to #149

`SpawnProcess` creates files to use for stdout and stderr which are opened but never closed, this leaks file descriptors that eventually cause larger test suites to fail on some systems (I encountered this with [rspec-core](/rspec/rspec-core) ).

This implementation closes the tmp files during the `SpawnProcess#stop(reader)` thus cleaning up the files and preventing the issue, however this causes an issue if steps attempt to access the files after the process has finished, to handle that eventuality the output of reading the streams is captured and used in the event of an `IOError`.

title: Cleanup SpawnProcess files after use
body:
`SpawnProcess` creates files to use for `stdout` and `stderr` which are opened but never closed, this leaks file descriptors that eventually cause larger test suites to fail on some systems (I encountered this with `rspec-core`).

So before we clear processess we clean them up by closing their io, for completness I also added this to `InProcess`.

title: Plugin API for greater speed
body:
Using Aruba to test a CLI with somewhat slow startup incurs a slow suite of scenarios. For example, this is true for JRuby-based CLIs. This includes Cucumber itself.

Aruba has well-known inputs and outputs:
- command
- command line arguments
- STDIN
- STDOUT
- STDERR
- exit status

We could make this a contract:

``` ruby
class Driver
  def run(cmd, args, stdin, stdout, stderr)
    # run it all
    return status
  end
end
```

Aruba would ship with a default driver, which forks a process like it currently does

However, people could supply their own driver following the same contract, which would be custom for the app under test, and would run it in the same ruby process.

I got this idea from cucumber/cucumber#432 where @mattwynne and @os97673 were discussing a slow test suite for Cucumber on JRuby.

title: Execute process as late as possible.
body: This gives the #stop! call chance to catch this process running and spec succeed. This should address #146.

title: "Aruba::Process#stop sends any output to the reader" fails quite often
body:
I observe following error quite often:

```
  1) Aruba::Process#stop sends any output to the reader
     Failure/Error: reader.should_receive(:stdout).with("yo\n")
       (Stub).stdout("yo\n")
           expected: 1 time
           received: 0 times
```

Actually it is so often, that it is hard to build Aruba for Fedora. The issue with this test is, that the 'echo "yo"' process finish so fast, that when the `process.stop` is called, it is already too late, therefore it cannot output into reader anything.

I had more luck rewriting the test as follows, i.e. executing the process as late as possible:

```
    describe "#stop" do
      it "sends any output to the reader" do
        reader = stub.as_null_object
        reader.should_receive(:stdout).with("yo\n")
        process.run!
        process.stop(reader, false)
      end
    end
```

However, I am afraid, that it can fail occasionally as well.

title: Tempfile leak leads to failure when many process was executed in a single cucumber run.
body:
#### Description of the problem

A cucumber features run will fail with "Too many open files" 
when large number of commands are executed in a single run.

I have found 2 possible workaround for the problem, which I will write below.
I can submit a pull request If someone can give me an advice which 
workaround is appropriate.
#### Minimum .feature to reproduce the problem:

env.rb

``` Ruby
require 'aruba/cucumber'
```

leak_test.feature

``` Ruby
Feature: leak test
  Scenario: run a command
    When I run `ls`
  #... repeat above for 1000 times or so
  Scenario: run a command
    When I run `ls`
```

Backtrace when number of opened file hit `ulimit -n` limit and scenarios starts failing.

```
 Scenario: run a command # /tmp/leaktest/leak_test.feature:2840
    When I run `ls`       # lib/aruba/cucumber.rb:60
      Too many open files - /tmp/aruba-out20130207-10084-18v0mg8-0 (Errno::EMFILE)
      /usr/lib/ruby/1.8/tempfile.rb:61:in `initialize'
      /usr/lib/ruby/1.8/tempfile.rb:61:in `open'
      /usr/lib/ruby/1.8/tempfile.rb:61:in `initialize'
      /home/y-higuchi/git/aruba/lib/aruba/process.rb:21:in `new'
      /home/y-higuchi/git/aruba/lib/aruba/process.rb:21:in `run!'
      /var/lib/gems/1.8/gems/aruba-0.5.1/lib/aruba/api.rb:296:in `run'
      /var/lib/gems/1.8/gems/aruba-0.5.1/lib/aruba/api.rb:13:in `chdir'
      /var/lib/gems/1.8/gems/aruba-0.5.1/lib/aruba/api.rb:13:in `in_current_dir'
      /var/lib/gems/1.8/gems/aruba-0.5.1/lib/aruba/api.rb:288:in `run'
      /var/lib/gems/1.8/gems/aruba-0.5.1/lib/aruba/api.rb:315:in `run_simple'
      /home/y-higuchi/git/aruba/lib/aruba/cucumber.rb:61
      /var/lib/gems/1.8/gems/cucumber-1.2.1/bin/../lib/cucumber/core_ext/instance_exec.rb:48:in `instance_exec'
```
#### Cause

Problem seems to be caused by the reference to [Tempfile instances created when a process is run](https://github.com/cucumber/aruba/blob/master/lib/aruba/process.rb#L21-L22) will never be GCed since the Process instance, which hold the reference to Tempfile, will [register itself](https://github.com/cucumber/aruba/blob/master/lib/aruba/api.rb#L295) to processes Array and the processes registered will never be freed throughout the cucumber run process.
#### Workaround

This problem can be worked around by either
[explicitly closing those Tempfiles](https://github.com/y-higuchi/aruba/compare/cucumber:master...close_tempfile_after_scenario) or by [clearing all the registered processes](https://github.com/y-higuchi/aruba/compare/remove_processes_after_scenario)
on cucumber's After hooks.
I have confirmed that both approach will pass aruba's existing `rake test` cases.

I wasn't sure which approach is better in general, and also wasn't sure whether this kind of workaround should be implemented by users on per project basis, or I should submit a pull request to make it a part of aruba itself, so I haven't submitted a pull request yet.

I couldn't think of a nice test case to capture this issue, so I do not have any additional test cases, but I can submit a pull request if that's ok.

title: Support for foreground processes
body:
Hello, is there existing functionality to test programs that run on the foreground? Example:

```
@terminate-processes-after
Given a directory named "config" exists
When I run `rails s`
Then the output should contain "Booting Thin"
And the following files should not exist:
  | logs/foo.log |
  | logs/bar.log |
```

The program (e.g. `rails s`) should be running while the `Then` statements are being asserted/processed. It is only terminated after the last step.

title: Unable to run process unless it's in PATH
body:
I've tried running a command via  relative path, then by changing to its directory and calling the command name directly. Neither works.

Does Aruba really limit you to PATH binaries only?

It would be good if you add support for setting of childprocess's `process.cwd` so that at the very least binaries in the cwd may be used.

For now the workaround is to pass a relative path to a command executor e.g. `sh -c relPath/script.sh` on UNIX.

title: Support for multiple commands in one step
body:
For example:

```
When I run commands
"""
command1
command2
command3
"""
```

I realise it's possible that a single command might need newlines in it e.g. passing a multiline commit message, so this would have to be a uniquely named step definition.

title: More backtick step definitions please
body:
Your use of backticks to avoid the need to escape single or double quotes when executing commands is very useful. I've come to `aruba` from `greenletters` which doesn't offer this simple yet effective utility.

It'd be great to see step definitions watching for process output offering the same style, e.g.
- `Given I wait for output to contain <backtick>#{STRING_CONTAINS_QUOTES}</backtick>`.
- `When I type <backtick>#{STRING_CONTAINS_QUOTES}</backtick>`

Of course the `<backtick>..</backtick>` tags used above should be replaced by literal backticks.

P.S. Is there a way to escape backticks in Github's Markdown? I haven't found one after Googling..

title: User-related steps & Simple process id aliases & Awaiting process termination
body:
I've implemented some of the following steps myself outside of Aruba. Would be great to see an implementation appear within the library.

1) User-related steps e.g.:

```
* `Given I am running as user #{USERNAME}`
* `Given I am running as user id #{UUID}`
* `Given I am in the home directory of user #{USERNAME}`.
* `Given I run #{CMD} as user #{USERNAME}`
* `Given file #{FILEPATH} is owned by #{USERNAME}`
```

2) Aliasing process ids. Much simpler than specifying the command in two places, and allows the same command to be executed multiple times concurrently.

```
* `Given I run #{CMD} with alias #{ALIAS}`
```

3) Awaiting process termination. This follows from (2).

```
* `Given I await termination of process #{ALIAS}
```

title: how do you use aruba???
body:
This is a plea for help.

I am trying to come up with tests that use aruba. But I can't find any really useful documentation about it. I get that it's a DSL of some kind, but I'm still new to DSLs and trying to figure out what is actually implemented where and how.

For example, just my first feature, I have this:

Feature: bare command gives help
  In order to see what the command does
  As a user
  I want to see the help text

  Scenario: App gives help
    When I run `obfuscate_database`
    Then the exit status should be 0
    And the banner should be present
    And the banner should document that this app takes options
    And the following options should be documented:
      |--version|
    And the banner should document that this app takes 1 arguments

And it fails, as I haven't coded that yet, but the last line is not implemented. The example shows that there is a step that matches

```
And the banner should document that this app takes no arguments
```

Am I expecting too much that this should be something already implemented in aruba, checking that a command line takes a certain number of arguments? I can't figure out where or how such a thing is implemented.

In just hacking at it, I tried the following things:

```
And the banner should document that this app takes 1 argument
And the banner should document that this app takes one arguments
And the banner should document that this app takes one argument
And the banner should document that this app takes arguments
```

All of these result in a pending test.

I know I'm going to want to try other things to make sure the command works as I want, but it's frustrating to supposedly have something that will test a CLI program, but not know anything about how to do so!

The web sites I've looked at are very short examples. I've not found anything that actually goes into any sort of detail. The aruba gem itself seems to have no rdocs, and the README is pretty useless in describing the actual DSL.

What am I not getting here?

There is an open issue at aruba's github about having rdocs, but I think I'm at a more naive level than even that would help. :(

body:

   If I use rbenv I don't get any errors in ruby runs of specs and
   cucumber, and jruby runs of specs also passes, only 11 cucumber tests
   fails with jruby.

I will try to investigate the difference between RVM and rbenv first
and letting (1) be second priority.

Apparently issue 1 does not occur when using childprocess 0.2.3 and using git bisect shows that https://github.com/jarib/childprocess/commit/5488ed454a727d6daf204259e4e80383e9c55065 is the offending commit.

title: How to assert on the first few lines of stdout without the command completing fully?
body:
Hi,

I have googled enough, but I can't seem to find an answer to this!!

I have this scenario wherein I am testing a command, which would actually go to soem remote server and do a bunch of different things, like starting launching VM's, and then running some process there and then shutting the VM down etc. The command itself, while performing these bunch of tasks spits some information out on the stdout.

I, instead of waiting for the whole time, would like to assert on certain few lines of output and move on. This is because, the command may take anywhere between 5 to 10 min depending on various different factors. Since this is an integration test that I am writing, I am suppose to be connecting to remote machines etc.

The problem that I am facing is that, although I get the output thrown away form the command in first few seconds,  I can't assert on them and move on declaring the tests as passing, as the test itself fails every time saying that its alive for more than 3 seconds. It does not makes sense for me to increase the timeout of a test to 10 minutes anyways. 

Can you please suggets, what should I do to resolve the issue??

title: 32-bit optimisation breaks JRuby for some platforms
body:
Only Solaris supports switching between 32-bit and 64-bit mode in
the same binary.  Every other platform has separate java binaries
and the -d32 (or -d64) switch will either do nothing or cause the
program to exit with a failure code.

title: HTML file contents matching
body: I have a custom RSpec formatter that outputs HTML files, and I would like to write an integration test around this using aruba. This is currently possible using the assert_file_contents matcher, but for this specific case the matcher has a too-narrow view of what does and does not match. The least amount that I need to make this matcher work for me is this: if the matcher could ignore differences in white space that is at the beginning and end of the lines of both the expected content and the actual content. A more sophisticated approach would be to canonicalize the HTML before comparing. This could also be useful for other formats, but seems much more domain-specific. To solve this problem, I am currently defining my own step that ignores the whitespace. Would a patch that added this functionality be considered for inclusion? If so, I will write up a PR.

```
      ./lib/aruba/api.rb:14:in `in_current_dir'
      ./lib/aruba/api.rb:267:in `run'
      ./lib/aruba/api.rb:294:in `run_simple'
      ./lib/aruba/cucumber.rb:57:in `/^I run `([^`]*)`$/'
      features/exit_statuses.feature:36:in `When I run `does_not_exist`'
    Then the exit status should be 1                # lib/aruba/cucumber.rb:126
```

If I get it right, childprocess was not handling "unknown command" errors before 0.2.4. It's now raising a `LaunchError` exception. The easiest fix for this is to force 0.2.3 in the gemspec. The nicest would be to catch and handle such exceptions.

title: Executing invalid command may result in false positives
body:
Consider the following example:

``` gherkin
Feature: Bad exec error handling

    Scenario: False positive
        When I run `thiscommanddoesnotexist`
        Then the output should contain "thiscommanddoesnotexist"

    Scenario: Example showing internal backtrace as command output in assertion error
        When I run `thiscommanddoesnotexist`
        Then the output should contain exactly ""
```

The executable that we are running does not exist, so whenever Ruby executes this command it will fail with `ENOENT`. However, the output (stderr) of this invocation is a backtrace that is internal to Cucumber creating a possibility for false positives.

My suggestion is to check if executing the child process command results in an exception and to raise that exception on the "When" step instead of silently continuing.

title: Tweak ENV vars for optimal JRuby performance
body:
As most people know, JRuby suffers from slow startup times even though it performs very well over the lifetime of a long-lived process.  Unfortunately, when you use aruba to test a command line tool on multiple ruby interpreters, including JRuby, you wind up with really, really slow performance on JRuby since the startup times are so bad and aruba is constantly shelling out to create new jruby processes.

There are a few ENV vars that most people aren't aware of that make a big difference:
- `JRUBY_OPTS=-X-C` disables the JIT, which is good for short lived scripts
- `JAVA_OPTS=-d32` forces it to use the client JVM which has better startup times than the server JVM

I got both of these settings from [this blog post](http://blog.headius.com/2010/03/jruby-startup-time-tips.html) for those who are interested.

I just [set these variables for rspec-core](https://github.com/rspec/rspec-core/commit/1592c942e0d0bd30127e3b8cf89194fe6fd118d6) and it cut **10 minutes** off of the build time.  It allows us to build rspec-core on travis using JRuby.

We can change this for all the other rspec repos as well...but it got me thinking: why not put these settings directly into aruba itself?  Not many people know about them, and given the short-lived nature of the processes aruba starts, I can't imagine a time when you wouldn't want them.

Thoughts?

title: Awkward path when running files in bin/
body:
If I'm working on a gem with an included executable in `bin/`, e.g.

```
> ls
bin/todo
lib/todo.rb
features/new_todo.feature
# etc.
```

I can't use a step like

```
Given I successfully run `bin/todo new 'My New TODO'`
```

instead, I have to 

```
Given I successfully run `../../bin/todo new 'My New TODO'`
```

I know I could set `@dirs` to be `['.']`, but I like the idea of the cwd being a tmp directory.  The only way around this is to make my own custom step that calls the internal one, unless I'm missing something.  I can think of two ways around this:
- Provide some sort of "executable name"-to-"actual path" mapping that can be configured, e.g. `@exec_map['todo'] =  '../../bin/todo' }` 
- Provide a way to modify the `PATH` environment variable during runtime

Is either of these preferred, or is there some other way to deal with this issue (or is it just me?)

title: Aruba.version to return version number
body:
If, as intended a library uses Aruba's steps, then to document the combined available steps in a feature the following step definition is required:

```
Then /^these steps are defined:$/ do |table|
  rsc = ::Cucumber::Runtime::SupportCode.new 'ui', :autoload_code_paths => 'lib/cuken/cucumber'
  rsc.load_files! ['lib/cuken/cucumber/file.rb', "#{ENV['GEM_HOME']}/gems/aruba-0.3.3/lib/aruba/cucumber.rb"]
  sd_array = rsc.step_definitions
  table.hashes.each do |hsh|
    sd_array.each{|sd| res = sd.regexp_source == %Q{/^#{hsh['step']}$/}; break if res}
  end
end
```

It is possible to avoid hard coding the Aruba version number, if Aruba.version returns the version string.

title: Store processes in array rather than hash
body:
Ensures consistent order of operations on 1.8.x and closes #48.

I also fixed the remaining warnings caused by using the run with quotes step in file_system_commands.feature.

title: Alternate command quotes
body:
I think that the regular expression for matching what commands to run is a bit to hungry for me, especially when I want to write new steps like:

  When I run "command foo bar" with "blah"

This commit provides an alternate syntax using backticks:

  When I run `command foo bar`

Thus allowing things like:

  When I run `command` with "blah"

The double quote syntax has not been removed, I've simply added an alternative.

-Anthony

title: We should eliminate should
body:
I'd like steps to be more definitive, and less redundant.  
`should` can be eliminated, it is everywhere and AFAICT adds no value.
Having just worked on these it is annoying and I really don't see exactly what value it adds that important enough to mean it has to be everywhere.

Would be interested in hearing what one loses by remove `should`

title: Handle ANSI color codes in strings
body:
Maybe the `exact` steps ought not strip out ANSI code, but the `contain` steps ought to remove ANSI color codes:

```
str.gsub(/\e\[(\d+)m/, '')
```

At the moment I just add this to any step files where I need this...

```
module Aruba
  class Process
    def remove_ansi_codes(str)
      str.gsub(/\e\[(\d+)m/, '')
    end
    def stdout
      wait_for_io do
        @out.rewind
        remove_ansi_codes(@out.read)
      end
    end
    def stderr
      wait_for_io do
        @err.rewind
        remove_ansi_codes(@err.read)
      end
    end
  end
end
```

title: @last_exit_status for an interactive session
body:
I just upgraded to 0.2.7 I can't tell for sure if this is still true in 0.3.2 because I can't run it yet, but I think so from reading the code.

I need to check the exit status from an interactive session. In an earlier iteration of the interactive stuff that I was previously using, I could do @interactive.status and check the status, but that's not offered on the new Process class. I did however notice that the status code is returned by Process#stop

So I wrote a step def:

```
When /^the console session ends$/ do
  @last_exit_status = @interactive.stop
end
```

Now I can use the @last_exit_status like you would for a non-interactive session. 

I don't know if there's a better way of building this in, or whether that step should ship with aruba, but I thought I'd flag it up.

title: Childprocess
body: Jarib released childprocess 0.1.6 today with support for stdin on *nix, JRuby and Windows. This branch replaces background_process with childprocess. I have more refactoring in mind, but it seems to work well enough, and it'll be good to finally have settled on a process control library.

title: Test Aruba with childprocess support on Windows
body: childprocess v0.1.6 contains support for stdin under Windows. Let's use this ticket to coordinate testing Aruba with childprocess on Windows. See my childprocess branch here: https://www.github.com/msassak/aruba/tree/childprocess to get started.

Aruba looks very nice; I may be using it in an upcoming command-line application I'm working on.

title: Rspec is a runtime dependency, not a development dependency
body:
rspec is listed as a development dependency, but the step_definitions in aruba/cucumber require rspec.  They use x.should include(y).

Here is some sample output from features using aruba:

Then the output should contain "xyz" # aruba-0.2.7/lib/aruba/cucumber.rb:110
  undefined method `include' for #Object:0x8113c62c (NoMethodError)

title: Escaping in multiline strings breaks compatibility and is not necessarily desired
body:
I have steps which look like this:

```
Then the output should contain:
     """
     REPLACE INTO some_table (some,columns,here) VALUES ("hello","world",42);
     """
```

(but with slightly longer SQL which doesn't easily fit on one line). v0.2.7, or at least commit 2f6b109, added unescaping of the string in this step (and others), which gives me errors like this:

```
   (eval):2: syntax error, unexpected tINTEGER, expecting $end
  ("hello","world",...
            ^ (SyntaxError)
```

In my opinion it's not desirable to unescape multiline strings. My interpretation of strings in a feature is that they show what is expected, verbatim. Having to escape quotes in a string that uses another kind of quoting (the triple quotes in this case), doesn't make sense.

It's also bad that this API breaking change was introduced in a patch-level version, but I've ranted about that in another issue.

title: 0.2.7 breaks things and should have been named 0.3.0
body:
I used 0.2.4 and then updated to 0.2.7 expecting a compatible API since both are in the 0.2.x range. However, 0.2.7 (or some version between 0.2.4 and 0.2.7) breaks compatibility:

```
require 'aruba'  
```

is suddenly no-op, and several of the "the output should contain" steps unescape the strings, which gives me weird errors (I've added a separate issue for this).

I realize that there's nothing you can do about this at this point, but could you please be more careful with versions in the future? The '~>' specifier in Rubygems is supposed to protect against incompatible versions, but it's useless when versions don't reflect API changes.

title: Make @announce also work for file operations
body: Currently the `@announce` tags do not work for file operations. It would be very helpful if they printed where Aruba created a file etc. It would also be nice if `@announce` could print the Aruba configuration so that it's easier to figure out what directory is used, e.g. `tmp/aruba`.

title: Document how the default directory can be changed
body:
Hi,

I had some trouble figuring out how @dirs can be used to change the default from "tmp/aruba" to something else. So I just documented it in README.rdoc.

Cheers,
Jan

title: Aruba 2.3 and higher no longer supports Windows OS
body: Aruba 2.3 introduced the background_process gem.  This gem is POSIX only, it requires 'pty'.  Aruba 2.2 was cross platform.  I assume that going POSIX only wasn't intentional.

title: Outputting a lot of data causes process to time out
body:
This can be reproduced by uncommenting the commented step in flushing.feature.

(When a process times out, the exit status is nil)

Mike, can you take a look at this? Not sure if this is an Aruba bug or a BackgroundProcess bug.

title: When I run "non-existent-command" passes (even though there is no command called non-existent-command)
body:
Hopefully the title says it all, but here's the detailed feature to try:

Feature: run exe
    as a user i'd like to run the exe'

```
Scenario: Run exe
    When I run "test_exe"
    Then I should see:
    """
    Hello World!
    """
```

The when step passes with aruba 0.2.4, cucumber 0.9.4, ruby 1.8.7 patch 249.

Setting the @announce tag will show the stderr output indicating test_exe is not found.  Shouldn't this be shown without the tag, instead of having the step pass?

title: Interactive improvements
body: This branch includes a number of bug fixes related to interactive support, a cleaner Aruba world and a new class that encapsulates process control. The new Process class should make it easier to deal with the cross-platform and cross interpreter issues that have been popping up since the switch to background_process, too.

body:
The following scenario passes...

```
    Then the output should contain "geddy-gen"
```

...but the following fails...

```
Scenario: Run geddy-gen app my_app
    When I run "geddy-gen app the_banana_stand"
    Then the output should contain "Created app the_banana_stand."
```

The error described is as follows...

```
expected: /Created\ app\ the_banana_stand\./, got: "/Users/ryancook/Developer/.rvm/gems/ruby-1.8.7-p248@geddy-gen_tests/gems/background_process-1.2/lib/background_process/background_process.rb:39:in `exec': Exec format error - /usr/local/bin/geddy-gen app the_banana_stand (Errno::ENOEXEC)
```

Any ideas? Something related to Node apps and background processes? Searching previous issues and the Google didn't yield much.

Thanks in advance for any help!

title: Verification step quoting/matching semantics
body:
Yo. 

While working on interactive support in Aruba, I was surprised a few times by the different ways different verification steps handle quoting and matching of input strings. So I think we should make them consistent. 

I've worked on this some in my interactive branch so that all steps with the word "contain" in them do this exactly:

1) Unescape
2) Compare using the include matcher (or just == in the case of the contain exactly steps)

While steps with "match" do this:

1) Convert to a regex with /#{match_string}/
2) Compare using the =~ matcher

This has problems. The check file content helper doesn't follow the rules (yet), but the biggest problem is that "include" doesn't provide a diff, which is really super helpful, but I was so frustrated at the time that I gladly took consistent quoting over that. Now that I've cooled off though I'm not so sure.

Whatever is decided, I'll make the changes gladly; I just want to make sure everything is consistent.

title: Added case insensitive step definitions
body:
I was trying to do a case insensitive match using a regex matcher, eg "/my text/i", and realized I couldn't so I added it just for regex's. I then realized if I was going to do it for one kind of matcher I should do it for all of them.

I'm a complete Ruby newbie so hopefully I haven't made too many silly mistakes and this is actually useful. I tried to make the additions as easy to use and understandable as possible. Where a regex is given I added a simple matcher for the trailing "i" like so "/blah/i". In the other matchers I added a regex for ", regardless of case," after the "should" or "should not." I then modified the api.rb to allow for case insensitive searches but made sure all the added parameters were optional with the default as case sensitive.

It's a bit verbose but it seems to be fairly clear when reading the Cucumber specs. Though I'm not sure if I should have made separate step definitions for the ", regardless of case," matchers. I may have been too clever by half in jamming that all into the same step.

I, of course, followed the behaviour-driven development protocol so there are tests for all added features.

Thank you for your time (and all the work you've put into this and the cucumber projects).

title: a directory/file named "whatever" should (not) exist
body:
- a file named "foo" should exist
- a file named "foo" should not exist
- a directory named "foo" should exist
- a directory named "foo" should not exist

Added these "Then" statements, as I found myself wanting to check a single file or directory's existence/absence while using aruba the last couple projects.

title: background_process does does not flush $stdout
body:
When testing a background process that streams significant amounts of data to $stdout the test eventually blocks on a write to $stdout and the test process halts indefinitely. This problem is a result of the switch to the background_process gem to implement the run command. An issue respecting this matter has been raised with the gem author 
http://github.com/timcharper/background_process/issues#issue/2
but no response has been forthcoming. Attempts to work around this matter by manually flushing $stdout in the test process itself has no effect on the behaviour of the test. Initially I thought that this was strictly a Ruby-1.9.2 problem as all tests passed when run under 1.8.7. However, by slightly increasing the amount of data sent to $stdout the problem also arises in Ruby-1.8.7. While this is, strictly speaking, a problem with the background_process gem itself, its presence makes the use of it in aruba somewhat problematic.

title: Use local commands
body:
Didn't think about this until working on Spork, where you want to use the local binary.  (Unlike, say, working on cucumber-rails, where the relevant binaries come from other projects.)

Currently I'm putting this at the top of Spork's env.rb:

```
ENV["PATH"] = File.expand_path(File.dirname(__FILE__) + "/../../bin") << ":" << ENV["PATH"]
```

This is to avoid any facepalm moments in future where I change Spork code and don't re-install the gem.  Question is, does Aruba need a step for this or an API means of making it easy? eg

```
Given $PATH includes "bin"
```

(which I don't like)

title: Multi-line string steps for "I should see stderr/stdout" etc
body:
Just working on the Spork code, updating the features to use Aruba.  I one of the Sporks steps was "the error output should contain" with a multiline string.  Currently Aruba doesn't have an equivalent:

```
Then the stderr should contain:
  """
  Loading Spork.prefork block...
  """
```

For completeness it'd be great to have all the steps (I should see, I should not see, I should see exactly, etc) available in total/stdout/stderr single and multi-line forms.

title: RVM has updated the gemset selector to +
body:
In RVM head as of today, you now have to do eg

```
rvm use 1.9.1+aruba
```

Instead of

```
rvm use 1.9.1%aruba
```

I can only find the announcement on Twitter: http://twitter.com/wayneeseguin/status/10848934147

As I've just updated to RVM head I'll create a micro-patch for this

title: Run commands in the background
body:
Sometimes it's necessary to run a process in the background. This can be because we want to interact with it from a different process. Examples:
- Sending data to the process via STDIN
- Run another process that needs the background process to be running in order to work

We can reuse some code from Cucumber:

http://github.com/aslakhellesoy/cucumber/blob/master/features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb#L35
http://github.com/aslakhellesoy/cucumber/blob/master/features/support/env.rb#L97

title: I should see matching for regex in partial output
body:
Hi, thanks for sharing this library.  Very handy.

I'll really like the simplicity of the existing "I should see" steps but I didn't spot one that handled regular expressions so I added a couple in a topic branch of my fork.

http://github.com/robertwahler/aruba/commit/2dc8e0260e56dc0aa25f356f1bdeac9bdaf4612f

I also added an announce-stdout to complement the existing announce tags here:

http://github.com/robertwahler/aruba/commit/a151980645014478b3707689723d6a259a1893d2

Please consider including these minor additions in your library.

Thanks, much.
robert wahler

title: Appending to a file doesn't add newlines
body: I'm working on this, the patch will make it self-explanatory

title: Duplicate step name if using Aruba in a Rails app
body: The step 'Then I should see "whatever"' is duplicated in web_steps.rb (provided when using cucumber-rails).  My thought is to remove the step (allowing only for multiline) or change the text to be more clear that it's related to the command line; thoughts?
